brandOverview.description: RSF represents a significant evolution, but not a revolution. The foundational brand qualities remain: Confident, Reliable, Authentic.

to.role: Brand = a catalyst for making things happen

lockups.overview: The lockup is a key element of the campaign's visual identity and must be used consistently to maintain clarity and impact.

horizontal.name: Horizontal Lockup
horizontal.usage: Best used in cinematic, widescreen applications

specifications.sizing: Never take up less than approximately 65% of a divided layout
specifications.fullBleed: Ideally sized to no less than ⅓ of the layout width for wider, landscape-sized assets, and ½ of the layout for assets with a ratio closer to 1:1 or 4:5
specifications.centerAlignment: When horizontally and vertically centered as a backdrop or title card, the horizontal lockup is ideally equal to approximately 65% of the layout width

vertical.name: Vertical Lockup (Stacked)
vertical.usage: Particularly useful in applications where horizontal space is limited, such as social media, digital placements, and narrow layouts

specifications.sizing: Ideally 75% of the layout width when horizontally and vertically centered as a backdrop or title card

endcardLockups.name: RSF Endcard Lockup Specifications
endcardLockups.rule: Use white lockup on top of imagery. No alternate color lockups.
donts: No custom sizes outside of spec

guidelines: Use negative space and ensure the lockup is positioned over an area of the image that does not obscure important or necessary details
High contrast between the lockup and the photo is essential for readability
Avoid placing the lockup over key elements of the image
Avoid using a Skyview fill when overlaying photos without sufficient contrast

colorOptions.name: Off-Black on Skyview
colorOptions.usage: More emotive and intrepid, ideal for applications looking to impart a sense of adventure

colorOptions.name: Skyview on Off-Black
colorOptions.usage: Most intense; used sparingly for moments of high-octane precision and thrill

brandPartnerships.guidelines: Logos should be at least 5x from the dividing line, with X equal to the height of the bar of the 'T' in the Vertical Lockup
brandPartnerships.dividingLine: Should be approximately ½ X in thickness
brandPartnerships.spacing: The spacing available for partner logos should not exceed that of 2x the Vertical Lockup

builtFordTough.description: The BFT Shield is synonymous with the power and fortitude of Ford Trucks, and is occasionally applied to truck-centric layouts as a graphic element
builtFordTough.usage: For static layouts, use the flat vector BFT Shield as it better marries with the world of RSF than its metallic, textured counterpart

animation.guideline: When animating a title card, a simple approach is often best
animation.frames: Whenever possible, the Lockup should appear over picture and animate on in three distinct frames—one for each element of the Lockup itself

horizontal: Don't apply any effects to the lockup, including but not limited to - drop shadows, glows, transparency, bevels, or gradients
Don't alter the line heights of the lockup
Don't adjust the kerning of the lockup
Don't alter the size or proportions of the logo within the lockup
Don't use title case for the lockup
Don't change the angle of the lockup, or place the lockup on its side facing down
vertical: Don't apply any effects to the lockup
Don't alter the line breaks of the lockup
Don't adjust the line spacing or kerning of the lockup
Don't alter the size or proportions of the logo within the lockup
Don't use title case for the lockup
Don't change the angle of the lockup, or place the lockup on its side facing down

typography.overview: Typography gives shape, weight and power to our voice. Meet American Grotesk - Ready Set Ford's family of typefaces.

primaryFont.name: American Grotesk
primaryFont.description: A modern reprisal of a Franklin Gothic, American Grotesk is intrepid, audacious, exciting and flexible - all while still feeling familiar

bold.name: Bold
bold.usage: Used for all Nameplates and CTAs as well as within Body Copy and Subheads for additional emphasis, if needed

regular.name: Regular
regular.usage: Used for all subheads and body copy

headlines.kerning: Set to 'Metrics', Having said this, typesetting can be subjective; designers are encouraged to manually kern letteform pairs should it feel warranted for aesthetic reasons
headlines.lineBreaks: Occasionally, tight leading can potentially cause letterforms to collide - particularly with diacritics (glyphs appearing below or above a letterform indicating a difference in pronunciation), punctuation such as commas, and characters with descenders (in our case, the letter 'Q')
headlines.diacritics: If a line can be broken in such a way as to avoid a collision, this is ideal, but understandably not possible all of the time. If this is the case, leading can be altered to accommodate the special character

nameplates.description: Nameplates are always set in bold and are always all-caps. This helps them stand apart from other elements. They employ 0 tracking, metrics kerning and a leading of approximately 110% of the font size

subheads.description: Subheads are set in Regular, employ 0 tracking, metrics kerning and a leading of approximately 110% of the font size

bodyCopy.description: Body Copy is set in Regular and employs 0 tracking, metrics kerning and a leading of approximately 130% of the font size

ctas.description: CTAs are set in Bold with 0 tracking and metrics kerning

hierarchy.description: We should try and maintain a relatively fixed value in the relationship of type sizes on any given layout

largeMediumFormat.name: Large Format / Out of Home
largeMediumFormat.subhead: Approximately 14%-17% the point size of the headline

mediumFormat.name: Medium Format
mediumFormat.description: For more intimate settings, aim for supporting elements to be 23% - 28% the point size of the headline

smallFormatMultipleSizes.name: Small format / Multiple Sizes
smallFormatMultipleSizes.description: In some places, there might be the need to combine multiple sizes (e.g. Headlines, Subheads and body copy) onto one layout - think web applications or publication materials. For this, we recommend there be a 50% difference in each element point size

alignment.headlines: Where possible, we aim to center-align Headlines to make a clear and confident statement. However, if a layout includes multiple supporting elements (e.g. Subheads, CTAs, etc) that might result in a less-pleasing shape if center-aligned, the headline can be left-aligned to accommodate
alignment.subheadsBodyCopy: All Subheads and Body copy should aim to be left-aligned with a 'right rag' - meaning the lines of text are not fully-justified, or extending directly to the end of the bounding box
alignment.nameplates: Nameplates should generally be left-aligned if broken into two lines. While right-alignment is mostly discouraged, a Nameplate can be right-aligned to create a more pleasing rag (or shape) if the layout necessitates
alignment.titleCards: All title cards should aim to be center-aligned

donts: Don't deviate from type settings (tracking, kerning, leading) unless you have to
Don't deviate from the use cases stipulated for each font
Don't use a font outside of the Ready Set Ford family
Don't distort type in any way

color.overview: Our color palette is a simple and contemporary nod to where we've been with an eye toward the future. It's flexible, dynamic and emotionally resonant in ways that can be turned up and down at a designer's discretion

skyviewBlue.name: Skyview Blue
skyviewBlue.description: Our familiar nod to Ford's timeless blue

offBlack.name: Off Black
offBlack.description: A dynamic and high energy supporting palette

skyviewOnWhite.description: Our hardest-working and standard color combination. For use in any neutral, sturdy or nimble application

offBlackOnSkyview.description: A little more emotive and intrepid, and ideal for applications looking to impart a sense of adventure

skyviewOnOffBlack.description: This is us at our most intense; used sparingly for moments of high-octane precision and thrill

exceptions.condition: In select instances, Off-Black on Skyview may feel too heavy for a particular setting, in which case White can be used as a fill
Black and white is an acceptable pairing when the use of color is prohibited

donts: Don't use colors outside of the Ready Set Ford palette
Don't pick a Division fill color that clashes with the photo it abuts
Don't fill a division with more than one color
Don't use color combinations outside of those suggested unless required to

layout.overview: The Ready Set Ford design system aims to make every moment impactful, no matter the shape. Here are some principles that guide how we show up

activatedSpace.name: Activated Space
activatedSpace.description: Big words, tight margins and divided layouts allow us to fill — or activate — all available space in dynamic ways, thereby making the most of any format while remaining clear, logical, and unmistakably Ford

contrast.name: Contrast
contrast.description: Photographic scale changes sit side-by-side with vibrant color pairings, bringing weight and personality to every layout

emotionalDepth.name: Emotional Depth
emotionalDepth.description: Each element of the toolkit is engineered to deliver a range of energy, utility and emotional depth

multiImageSystem.description: Each layout may use multiple images, but they must maintain balance in scale, clarity, and color relationships

system.name: 8px Grid System
system.description: Use an 8px base grid for spacing, padding, and layout consistency

margins.description: Margins give our layouts balance and focus. They're also an essential building block to determine the space between each component within
margins.calculation: Margins are applied by calculating a percentage of the width of an asset. This allows for flexibility, as there's no one-size-fits-all margin setting
margins.bestPractices: Wider spaces tend to benefit from smaller percentages, while narrower spaces tend to benefit from higher percentages. To maintain a consistent feel across all communications, try not to go below 1% or above 15%

lockupPadding.name: Endcard Lockup Padding
lockupPadding.description: Padding around end card lockups should snap to the 8px grid to maintain visual balance across formats

gutters.description: Gutters are the spacing elements applied to layouts. Think of them as padding - keeping type and graphic elements locked to them from being too flush with a change in imagery or color field
gutters.application: Gutters should always be equal to the width of document margins. Each division should have gutters on all sides, to which all graphic elements (Headlines, Subheads, CTAs) align

buttons.description: Buttons should feel sturdy and clickable, with consistent padding and rounded-corner style

ctas.description: CTAs are calls to action. They are used in digital applications to drive traffic to a specific place or to perform an action
ctas.placement: Where possible, the placement should aim to activate space — that is, occupy a pole (or corner) not already being used by another element. This creates a sense of balance and fullness, while carving out spacing for each
ctas.positioning: Can appear beneath a Headline and Subhead, given that there isn't sufficient room on the bottommost poles of the layout to accommodate it

bftShield.description: The BFT Shield is synonymous with the power and fortitude of Ford Trucks
bftShield.usage: Treated much like any other supporting graphic element — aligned to a pole in a way that gives it a sense of space and purpose from surrounding elements. Because it contains the Ford Script, it's ideal to keep it 'separate' from the RSF lockup as much as possible so as to minimize the feel of competing branding
bftShield.sizing: Ideal sizing for the BFT Shield within layouts: ideally 2-3x the size of document margins
bftShield.placement: In instances where the BFT Shield is treated as a supporting graphic element — aligned to a pole in a way that gives it a sense of space and purpose from surrounding elements

headlines.marginToMargin: Whenever possible, headlines will extend to fill the length of the document or division margins (the gutters we talked about on the previous page,) either top-to-bottom or left-to-right. This will occasionally need to vary to accommodate other supporting elements within the layout
headlines.succinct: The ideal headline is short and punchy, between three to eight words

nameplates.stickToThePoles: Like all supportive design elements (Headlines, Subheads, CTAs,) the Nameplate should be locked to the pole — that's to say the corners: upper-left, lower-left, upper-right or lower-right — of a division section if a divided layout is being used or the document corners if a full bleed image is being used. This placement helps the elements feel anchored to and supportive of the surrounding layout
nameplates.stayClose: While the Nameplate placement is up to you, try to ensure that it stays within reasonable proximity to vehicle it describes: either by placing it the a corner of a photo of the vehicle itself, or within the headline portion of a divided layout
nameplates.asReminder: Nameplates are always set in all caps

subheads.stayCloseToHeadline: If working with a divided space to house a Headline, try and keep the Subhead within a stone's throw: this could be directly beneath the Headline in question, or at the bottommost pole aligned with the Headline. This won't always be possible for practical or aesthetic reasons, and if that's the case, just try and keep the Subhead as close as is reasonable within the layout

placement.belowHeadline: The Subhead is positioned below the headline with a spacing equal to the layout margins. This placement is ideal when other elements occupy the poles of the division
placement.lowerLeft: The Subhead is placed in the lower left portion of the layout division
placement.middleColumn: The Subhead occupies the middle column of the full-bleed layout. This is acceptable in instances like the example as the Subhead is in close enough proximity to the headline to still feel connected to it

dividing.overview: To enhance, focus, and organize, layouts can be split on both horizontal and vertical gridlines that occupy a neutral color separate from the image. This is depicted in the examples at right

principles.divideSpacesEvenly: In this guide, we mandate always dividing the layout into even spaces, whether that's halving or thirding. Any further divisions within those divided spaces should always be by equal thirds. This keeps the layout organized while preventing layouts from becoming too complex to easily understand
principles.maxFourQuadrants: By quadrants, we mean spaces created by divisions. This prevents layouts from becoming too complex
principles.fullBleed: You are not required to split a layout if space, content or aesthetic needs otherwise. Full-bleed layouts without a division are suited for simple, declarative moments with strong, short headlines and little-to-no accompanying subheads or body copy. Think a masthead image or a social post
principles.oneThird: Like full-bleed, one third divisions rely on a single image to support a headline, and can easier-accommodate other graphic elements in the space created by the split. They should be used when a panoramic image needs room to breathe apart from other graphic elements
principles.bisected: A bisected division splits headline space and image space evenly, and is perfect for straightforward messaging that doesn't require many other supporting elements

types.oneThird: Like full-bleed, one third divisions rely on a single image to support a headline, and can easier-accommodate other graphic elements in the space created by the split
types.bisected: A bisected division splits headline space and image space evenly, and is perfect for straightforward messaging
types.trisected: Divisions allow for more than one image to support a headline. Trisected divisions are ideal when two images can bookend a headline
types.fourQuadrants: Trisected should encourage you to think about layout in a new way: a headline need not always be text, and in instances like this example headspace can be divided. Think most leaderboard and billboard ads, or any format that is horizontal in nature and narrow
types.verticalTwoImage: This division utilizes two images: stacked vertically, and is generally best when accommodating landscape-centric photography
types.horizontalTwoImage: Also utilizing two images, abutting horizontally is composed to work best in tight layouts where horizontal space greatly outnumbers vertical space - think most leaderboard or banner ads
types.threeImage: In which one vertically divided quadrant is divided to form two equal quadrants

guidelines: A max of four 'quadrants' per layout
Aim to keep Headlines confined to one divided quadrant

principles.minimalistic: Imagery must be minimalistic, uncluttered, clean, and high-impact
principles.balance: Multiple images per layout should feel balanced in scale and color
principles.clarity: Maintain balance in scale, clarity, and color relationships

overall.approach: We're shifting from an approach that centers on vehicle photography, to a multi-dimensional style that heroes both customer and product equally across the board
overall.flexibility: This approach and our new multi-image layout system allows for flexibility, using photos of: Product, Portraiture of people, And People + Product together

customerCentric.name: Customer Centric - Not Just Vehicle Centric

peoplePortrayal.description: People should appear heroic, confident, capable, determined, and authentic — not staged or posed for decoration

actionOriented.name: Action-Oriented
actionOriented.description: Prefer motion and energy: 9/10 images should feel active, not static

extremeFraming.description: Leverage extreme close-ups and wides to create drama and contrast between human and machine

peopleVehicle.description: Show people and vehicles together in a way that highlights capability, performance, and purpose

product3D.description: Use 3D renders or animations to highlight engineering, functionality, and performance

colorStyle.description: Imagery should be bold, rich, crisp, energetic, and high-contrast. Natural palettes 'on their best day.' Boost contrast as needed; only increase saturation where lacking

toneOfVoice.brandPurpose: Ford exists to take the capability that's in every person, and enable it with the things we build

inspiring.description: No matter how much they've done, people are always capable of more. Our goal is to craft a message that inspires others to get out there and do more

determined.description: Good things may come to those who wait, but great things come to those who take action. We see each day as an opportunity for bigger and better things, and we intend to seize that opportunity. You can feel this sense of determination in our voice: grit meets gusto

impassioned.description: When it comes to talking about what we do & why we do it, we're not understated. Or stoic. Or resolute. We're obsessed. This sense of passion is shared with our customers, and that's why our voice should aspire to sound less like a big automotive brand, and more like a human being expressing their passion

taglineModularity.overview: Modularity is one of the strengths of our new tagline. Filling in the blank creates bespoke step-up lines for individual pieces of work

usage.regional: Modularity of READY SET FORD should only be used in the U.S. at launch, in English

guidelines.actionOriented: Each modular line needs to A: convey a clear action/activity/emotional benefit and B: clearly speak to one of our three mindsets (Thrill/Adventure/Build)
guidelines.aspirational: Avoid generic/flat-footed language. We want modular lines that convey an emotion and have a sense of attitude
guidelines.simple: Keep it short, high-energy, and punchy – embrace double meanings and giving new meaning to familiar phrases
guidelines.benefitFocused: Use the modular line to illustrate the benefit of the feature, not just call out the feature name

READY. SET. WIPE THAT SMILE ON YOUR FACE
adventure: READY. SET. HEAD FOR THE HILLS

READY. SET. PUT YOURSELF OUT THERE
READY. SET. COME BACK WITH A STORY
build: READY. SET. ROLL UP THOSE SLEEVES
READY. SET. GET THINGS DONE BY THE TON
capability: READY. SET. FREE THOSE HANDS UP
READY. SET. PUT YOUR BACKUP INTO IT
READY. SET. BRING THE SERVICE CENTER TO YOU
READY. SET. LAY IT ALL ON THE LINE
community: READY. SET. BUILD EACH OTHER UP
READY. SET. RUN AT THE FIRE

style.description: Animations should feel clean, elevated, nimble, energetic, confident, and smooth — never hectic or disorienting

layoutDonts: Don't let elements float in space - unless those elements are titles, endcards, or something similar
Don't divide spaces in ways that aren't those illustrated within this guide
Don't divide spaces in ways that aren't at 90° angles
Don't divide the lockup into more than 4 quadrants
Don't split layouts in a way that doesn't make the best use of space
Don't clutter a layout. Get rid of everything that doesn't need to be there
